questions.text: A patient experiences sudden breathlessness following a subclavian vein cannulation. Upon examination, there are absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion on one side of the chest. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iatrogenic Pneumothorax

 

Latrogenic pneumothorax is a type of traumatic pneumothorax that occurs following medical procedures. The clinical presentation of sudden breathlessness after subclavian vein cannulation with absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion is classic for pneumothorax. The leading causes of iatrogenic pneumothorax include transthoracic needle aspiration, thoracentesis, and the insertion of central intravenous catheters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malposition of central venous catheter: While catheter malposition can cause complications, it would not produce the physical exam findings of absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance characteristic of air in the pleural space.

 

Option C. Air embolism via air embolus: Air embolism would present with different symptoms including neurological deficits, cardiovascular collapse, or pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, but would not cause absent breath sounds with hyper-resonance on percussion.

 

Option D. Cardiac Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias can occur during central line placement but would present with palpitations, dizziness, or hemodynamic instability without the characteristic respiratory exam findings noted in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Iatrogenic pneumothorax is a common complication of central venous catheterization, particularly with the subclavian approach, presenting with sudden breathlessness, absent breath sounds, and hyper-resonance on percussion of the affected side.

questions.text: A diabetic patient was advised exercise by the treating physician. The glucose transporter which is insulin sensitive is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glut 4

 

Glucose transporter 4 (Glut 4) is the insulin-sensitive glucose transporter found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. Insulin plays a key role in regulating glucose uptake in these tissues by promoting the translocation of Glut 4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane, thereby enhancing glucose entry into the cell. This insulin-mediated mechanism is crucial in maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during states of increased energy demand, such as exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glut 1: This glucose transporter is found in nearly all tissues, including the brain, and facilitates the basal uptake of glucose independently of insulin. It is not insulin-sensitive.

 

Option B. Glut 2: Glut 2 is mainly present in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the renal tubules, where it helps regulate glucose levels.

 

Option C. Glut 3: This transporter is primarily located in neurons and the placenta, ensuring high-affinity glucose uptake in tissues with high glucose demand. It is not regulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glut 4 is the only glucose transporter that is insulin-sensitive, primarily found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle, where it facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin.

choices.text: Delivery of the posterior shoulder

questions.text: During delivery of a 24 y primigravida, the head comes out, but the shoulders fail to deliver. McRoberts maneuver is immediately done but the shoulders still fail to deliver. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supra-pubic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of shoulder dystocia, where the baby's shoulders fail to deliver after the head, specific maneuvers are performed in a stepwise manner. The McRoberts maneuver, which involves hyperflexion and abduction of the mother's thighs onto her abdomen, is the first step and is successful in resolving many cases by reducing the angle of the pelvis.

 

If the McRoberts maneuver is unsuccessful, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure. This involves an assistant applying pressure just above the pubic bone to help dislodge the anterior shoulder from behind the pubic symphysis. This maneuver is often performed simultaneously with the McRoberts maneuver but is listed next in the shoulder dystocia drill.

 

HELPER mnemonic from Baxley and Gobbo, 2004, is a guideline for managing obstetric emergencies:

 

  • H: Call for Help
  • E: Evaluate for Episiotomy
  • L: Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre)
  • P: Suprapubic Pressure
  • E: Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation)
  • R: Remove the posterior arm
  • R: Roll the patient (Gaskin maneuver)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of the posterior shoulder: This is a subsequent step if supra-pubic pressure and internal rotation maneuver fail.

 

Option B. Internal rotation: This includes maneuver like the Woods corkscrew or Rubin maneuver and is considered after supra-pubic pressure fails.

 

Option D. Zavanelli maneuver: This is a last-resort measure where the baby's head is pushed back into the birth canal for an emergency cesarean section.

 

Educational objective:

 

If the McRoberts maneuver fails to resolve shoulder dystocia, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure to help dislodge the anterior shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the shown congenital anomaly in which the intestinal loops are present outside the abdominal cavity covered by amniotic membrane. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a congenital anomaly known as omphalocele. This condition is characterized by the presence of intestinal loops and sometimes other abdominal organs outside the abdominal cavity. These organs are covered by a transparent sac composed of the amniotic membrane, peritoneum, and Wharton's jelly.

 

Omphalocele Characteristics: In omphalocele, the herniated organs protrude through the umbilical ring and are covered by the amniotic membrane. This condition is associated with various other congenital anomalies and syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: This is incorrect. In gastroschisis, the intestines protrude through a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilical cord, without any covering membrane. The exposed intestines are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which distinguishes it from omphalocele.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. While an omphalocele can be associated with various anomalies, the specific mention of an enteric cyst is not a standard characteristic of typical omphalocele presentations.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. Gastroschisis involves exposed intestines without a covering membrane. The presence of an enteric cyst does not align with the typical presentation of gastroschisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the intestines and possibly other organs protrude through the umbilical ring, covered by the amniotic membrane. This differentiates it from gastroschisis, where the intestines are exposed without a covering membrane.

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

choices.text: 70 percent of the drug undergoes first pass metabolism in liver.
The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition.
The drug is 30 percent potent in producing therapeutic effect.
30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

questions.text: What does it mean when a drug has a bioavailability of 30 percent? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans D. 30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

 

This statement accurately defines bioavailability. Bioavailability is the percentage of an administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation without being metabolized or changed. In this case, a bioavailability of 30 percent means that only 30 percent of the drug dose reaches the systemic circulation, while the rest may be eliminated or metabolized before reaching the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70 percent of the drug undergoes first-pass metabolism in the liver: This statement is not a direct explanation of bioavailability but is related to the fate of the drug after absorption. If 30 percent is bioavailability, then 70 percent of drug is either not absorbed or undergo first pass metabolism. First-pass metabolism in the liver can reduce the amount of drug available for systemic circulation, but it doesn't define bioavailability.

 

Option B. The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition: This statement is incorrect. Bioavailability is not related to the purity of a drug but rather to its absorption and availability in the bloodstream.

 

Option C. The drug is 30 percent potent in producing a therapeutic effect: This statement is not an accurate description of bioavailability. Potency refers to the strength or concentration of a drug required to produce a specific effect, while bioavailability is about how much of the administered dose reaches the systemic circulation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: In CN III palsy, which of the following is not affected? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

Cranial Nerve III (CN III), also known as the oculomotor nerve, innervates several muscles responsible for eye movements and eyelid elevation. These muscles include the superior rectus (elevation), medial rectus (adduction), inferior rectus (depression), and inferior oblique (extorsion and elevation in adduction). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eyelid.

 

Abduction is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI), not the oculomotor nerve. Therefore, abduction is not affected in CN III palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

In CN III palsy, the functions of these muscles are compromised, leading to issues such as:

 

Option A. Elevation: Elevation is affected due to the involvement of the superior rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option B. Adduction: Adduction is affected due to the involvement of the medial rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CN III palsy, abduction is not affected because it is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI).

questions.text: Identify the condition:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body)
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma. Hemangioma of bone is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull. Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve the metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma. Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

choices.text: Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Isthmus because of narrowest area
Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla because of narrowest area

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmus because of narrowest area

 

The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the tube, which makes it an ideal site for ligation. One key reason for selecting this site is that it preserves the broader segments of the tube, such as the ampulla, which are essential if recanalization (reversal of the ligation) is needed later. By ligating the narrowest part, the wider and more functionally significant areas remain intact, facilitating easier and more successful surgical reanastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: This is incorrect because the reason for ligating at the isthmus is primarily its narrowness, not muscle structure.

 

Option C. Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: The ampulla is not the preferred site for ligation because it is wider and more functionally significant. Ligation here would complicate future recanalization procedures.

 

Option D. Ampulla because of narrowest area: This is incorrect because the ampulla is not the narrowest part of the fallopian tube; the isthmus is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the most common site for tubal ligation due to its narrowness, which preserves the broader, more functional parts of the tube, making recanalization easier if needed in the future.

questions.text: Which ovarian tumor is associated with Meig's Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroma

 

Meigs' syndrome is specifically defined as the presence of ascites and right side hydrothorax in association with fibroma of the ovary. This classic triad features a benign solid ovarian tumor with accompanying fluid collections. The syndrome is characterized by spontaneous remission of both the ascites and hydrothorax following removal of the tumor. While other ovarian tumors may rarely present with similar findings, the term "Meigs' syndrome" properly refers to this specific association with ovarian fibroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucous cyst of ovary: Mucous cysts (mucinous cystadenomas) are multiloculated cysts containing mucinous material that can grow to large sizes, but they are not linked to the classic triad seen in Meigs' syndrome. These cysts can be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei if rupture occurs, but not with hydrothorax.

 

Option C. Struma Ovarii: Struma ovarii is a specialized form of ovarian teratoma composed primarily of thyroid tissue. It accounts for less than 3% of mature teratomas and can sometimes produce thyroid hormones leading to hyperthyroidism, but it doesn't cause the characteristic ascites and hydrothorax seen in Meigs' syndrome.

 

Option D. Teratoma: Teratomas (dermoid cysts) contain elements from all three germ layers and are prone to torsion as they are light and float in the peritoneum. However, they do not cause the characteristic ascites and hydrothorax seen in Meigs' syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meigs' syndrome is specifically characterized by the triad of ovarian fibroma, ascites, and right-sided hydrothorax, with all symptoms resolving after tumor removal.

questions.text: IUCD can be inserted after delivery till? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 48hrs


An Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD), specifically the Copper T, can be inserted immediately after delivery as part of postpartum family planning. The optimal time frames for insertion include:

 

  1. Post-placental insertion: Within 10 minutes of placental delivery, commonly done when the patient is highly motivated.
  2. Early postpartum insertion: From 10 minutes up to 48 hours after delivery.
  3. Intra-caesarean insertion: At the time of cesarean section.
  4. Late postpartum – After 6 weeks 

 

Early postpartum IUCD insertion is considered safe and effective during this period due to the lower risk of expulsion and higher motivation of the patient.

 

Note -  48hrs to 6 weeks’ period is not suitable for IUCD insertion due to the high risk of expulsion and complications as the uterus is actively involuting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery, but not between 48 hours to 6 weeks due to the high risk of expulsion during this time.

questions.text: A long-standing smoker has shortness of breath, and spirometry shows FEV₁ 60% with FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.6. Which of the following is the likely cause of the findings in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) COPD

 

The spirometry findings are classic for an obstructive lung disorder. An FEV₁ less than 80% and an FEV₁/FVC ratio less than 0.7 are diagnostic criteria for obstructive lung disease. The patient's long-standing smoking history and these specific spirometry results strongly point to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), which includes conditions like chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Silicosis: This is a restrictive lung disorder caused by inhalation of silica dust, typically seen in workers like miners and sandblasters. It would show a reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio characteristic of restrictive lung diseases, not obstructive.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease: Another restrictive lung disorder characterized by inflammation and scarring of lung tissue. It would also demonstrate reduced lung volumes and a decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio typical of restrictive diseases.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: While associated with smoking, this is a space-occupying lesion that might affect lung function but is not primarily a cause of obstructive lung disease. It would not typically cause the classic spirometry changes seen in this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.7 indicates obstructive lung disease. COPD is the most common obstructive lung disease in smokers, while conditions like silicosis and interstitial lung disease present with restrictive patterns (normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio).

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and white line of Frenkel on X-ray? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C is crucial for the absorption of iron in the body as it converts ferric ion (Fe³⁺) to ferrous ion (Fe²⁺), the form in which iron is best absorbed in the intestine. A deficiency of vitamin C can impair iron absorption, leading to iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, vitamin C is essential for the post-translational modification of collagen, where proline is converted to hydroxyproline and lysine to hydroxylysine. This modification strengthens collagen fibers; without sufficient vitamin C, collagen becomes weak, leading to symptoms such as bleeding gums due to fragile blood vessels. The white line of Frenkel on X-ray is another characteristic sign of scurvy, a condition resulting from severe vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia (low neutrophil count), and hypopigmentation, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the specific X-ray findings mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron deficiency leads to anemia, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the white line of Frenkel on X-ray, which are specific to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Zinc: Zinc deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, and immune dysfunction, but it does not cause the symptoms outlined in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and the white line of Frenkel on X-ray due to impaired iron absorption and defective collagen synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not result in water hardness? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Calcium carbonate

 

Hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved minerals, particularly calcium and magnesium ions. These minerals can come from various sources, such as natural deposits in soil and rocks, or from industrial and domestic activities.

 

There are two types of hardness of water:

 

Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.

 

Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

choices.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L
pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg
pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A district in Madhya Pradesh has CBR 19/1000 LB and CDR is 6/1000 LB. Find the annual growth rate of the district. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.3%

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated using the formula:

 

Annual Growth Rate (AGR) = Crude Birth Rate (CBR) − Crude Death Rate (CDR)

 

In this case:

 

  • CBR = 19 per 1000 live births
  • CDR = 6 per 1000 live births

 

AGR = 19−6 = 13 per 1000

 

To express this as a percentage (which is the standard form for growth rates), you multiply by 0.1:

 

13 × 0.1 = 1.3%

 

Therefore, the annual growth rate for this district is 1.3%.

 

Additional Information –

 

  • Mid-year population is refer to the 1st of July.
  • India is in Stage 3 of Demographic cycle

 

Educational Objective:

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated by subtracting the Crude Death Rate (CDR) from the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and then expressing this difference as a percentage.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to ≤ 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to ≤ 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to ≤ 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

questions.text: A man comes to the OPD with complaints of sinusitis and breathing difficulty. He also gives a history of infertility for the past few years. On further examination, thoracic cavity organs were found to be on the opposite side. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome


Kartagener syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (a condition where the thoracic and abdominal organs are mirrored from their normal positions).

 

The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a defect in the structure and function of cilia, which are hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and other parts of the body. These cilia are responsible for moving mucus and other substances along the respiratory tract, as well as for ensuring proper placement of organs during embryonic development.

 

In this case, the patient's symptoms of sinusitis, breathing difficulties, and history of infertility, combined with the finding of situs inversus, strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome. The infertility is due to immotile sperm in males, which is also caused by defective cilia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: This condition typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness. It is not associated with situs inversus or infertility.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not associated with situs inversus, sinusitis, or bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Although it can cause chronic cough and sinusitis, it is not associated with situs inversus or infertility. Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently widened, leading to frequent lung infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility, all of which result from defective ciliary function.

choices.text: May be confused with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome

questions.text: All of the following statements about Menetrier’s disease are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Usually increased acid secretion

 

Explanation:

 

Ménétrier's disease is characterized by decreased gastric acid secretion, not increased secretion. The disease features massive foveolar hyperplasia with marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells, which are responsible for acid production. Histologically, there is hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucous cells with a marked reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a premalignant condition: Ménétrier's disease is considered premalignant by some clinicians, though the exact risk of neoplastic progression is not well defined.

 

Option C. May be confused with Zollinger: Ellison Syndrome - Both conditions can present with similar symptoms including abdominal pain, though ZES has increased acid secretion while Ménétrier's has decreased acid secretion.

 

Option D. Associated with protein: losing enteropathy - Twenty to 100% of patients with Ménétrier's disease develop a protein-losing gastropathy due to hypersecretion of gastric mucus, accompanied by hypoalbuminemia and edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Ménétrier's disease is characterized by hypochlorhydria (decreased acid secretion) due to parietal cell loss, which distinguishes it from hypersecretory conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome despite potential overlap in clinical presentation.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a Veress needle which has distinctive features:

 

  • Used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique
  • Has a blunt tip that advances and spring-loaded sharp outer cannula
  • When resistance is overcome, blunt tip springs forward preventing injury to intraabdominal organs
  • Usually inserted in left hypochondrium (Palmer's point) or periumbilical
  • Characteristic "pop" sound heard when it enters peritoneal cavity
  • Can be confirmed by saline drop test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Quincke needle: Incorrect as this is a spinal needle with sharp bevel used for diagnostic/therapeutic lumbar puncture

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: Incorrect as this is a bone marrow biopsy needle

 

Option D. Aspiration needle: Incorrect as this is for aspiration of fluid collections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Veress needle is used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique and has a characteristic spring-loaded mechanism.

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with history suggestive of tuberculosis. Culture media used commonly in India is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LJ medium

 

In India, Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium has been the traditional and most commonly used culture media for TB diagnosis. According to the transcript, under the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP), two main culture methods are used:

 

  • LJ medium (Lowenstein Jensen medium) - Traditional method
  • Automated liquid culture - Newer method (like Versatrack, BACTEC MGIT 960, BACTALERT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler medium: Incorrect because. Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option C. Thayer Martin medium: Incorrect because. This is selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis

 

Option D. Macconkey agar: Incorrect because. Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Educational Objective:

 

LJ (Lowenstein Jensen) medium is the traditional and commonly used culture media for tuberculosis diagnosis in India, along with newer automated liquid culture systems under NTEP.

questions.text: While preparing a slide for histopathological examination (HPE), a box-like gross appearance is seen in the scanner view. In which of the following conditions is this seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morphea

 

The box-like or squared-off appearance observed in the histopathological slide is characteristic of Morphea, also known as localized scleroderma. This appearance results from marked sclerosis of the collagen throughout the reticular dermis, which can sometimes extend to the subcutaneous fat. Morphea is a type of localized scleroderma where the skin becomes hard and tight due to excessive collagen deposition. This histological feature is distinctive and helps differentiate Morphea from other conditions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen nitidus: This condition typically shows a "claw clutching ball" appearance histologically, where inflammatory cells are tightly packed within the dermal papillae. This appearance is different from the box-like structure seen in Morphea.

 

 

Option B. Lichen planopilaris: Lichen planopilaris is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicles, leading to scarring alopecia. Hair follicles or their remnants would be visible in the histological image, which is not the case in the presented slide.

 

 

Option D. Lichen amyloidosis: This condition would usually show deposits of amyloid, often highlighted with a polarized microscope, creating a distinctive pattern, but not the box-like appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morphea, a localized form of scleroderma, is identified by a box-like or squared-off appearance on histopathological slides due to marked collagen sclerosis in the dermis.

choices.text: Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia
Associated with normal survival of neutrophils

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pelger-Huet Anomaly is false? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Associated with large platelets.

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse, clumped chromatin, typically appearing as bilobed ("pince-nez" or "spectacle-shaped") nuclei. It is not associated with large platelets. The anomaly affects granulocyte nuclear segmentation but does not impact platelet morphology. Large platelets are more commonly associated with other conditions such as immune thrombocytopenia, Bernard-Soulier syndrome, or May-Hegglin anomaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited trait with hypo segmented neutrophils - This is a true statement. The hereditary form of Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse clumped chromatin and normal neutrophil function.

 

Option B. Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia - This is a true statement. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells are commonly seen in myelodysplastic syndromes. These cells are one of the characteristic findings of dysgranulopoiesis in MDS.

 

Option C. Associated with normal survival of neutrophils - This is a true statement. Despite the nuclear abnormality, neutrophil function and survival remain normal in hereditary Pelger-Huet anomaly. The condition is generally benign and does not affect the functional capabilities of neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly affects nuclear segmentation of neutrophils but does not impact platelet morphology; the abnormal hypo segmented neutrophils retain normal function and survival time in the hereditary form of the condition.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia
Von Willebrand disease type 1

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

 

The symptoms described in the question—acute severe pain episodes in the fingers and toes—are characteristic of vaso-occlusive crises, which are a hallmark of sickle cell anemia. These episodes are caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells that obstruct blood flow in small blood vessels, leading to ischemic pain. This condition results from a mutation leading to the production of hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under low oxygen conditions, distorting the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

 

 

  • HbF, ↑ WBC, LDH is predictive of clinical severity.
  • Target Hb < 10g/dL (To minimize risk of Sickling episodes due to high viscosity).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-thalassemia: This condition involves a deficiency in the production of alpha globin chains but does not typically manifest with acute pain episodes like sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Beta-thalassemia: Like alpha-thalassemia, this involves a problem with globin chain production (beta chains in this case) and also does not typically present with acute pain episodes.

 

Option D. Von Willebrand disease type 1: This is a bleeding disorder, not a hemoglobinopathy, characterized by a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which helps with blood clotting. It would more commonly present with symptoms related to bleeding rather than ischemic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia should be suspected in patients who present with episodic acute pain in the extremities, a symptom commonly resulting from vaso-occlusive crises due to abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

choices.text: Acute motor axonal neuropathy
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy
Miller Fisher syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

 

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) in the United States and Europe. It presents with rapidly ascending motor weakness and, at times, sensory disturbances in the form of paresthesia. The pathological hallmark of AIDP is the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to slow nerve conduction velocities as detected on electromyography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): While AMAN is more common in certain regions like East Asia, it is less prevalent than AIDP in most parts of the world. AMAN is characterized by the involvement of motor fibers without significant demyelination.

 

Option C. Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN): Similar to AMAN but involves both motor and sensory fibers. It is generally more severe but less common than AIDP.

 

Option D. Miller Fisher syndrome: A rare variant of GBS that is characterized by ataxia, areflexia, and ophthalmoplegia. It is considered a variant of GBS associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AIDP is the most common type of GBS presenting with ascending motor weakness with occasional distal sensory paresthesia due to demyelination of posterior column.

 

Axonal variants:

 

  • AMAN (Acute motor axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a    
  • AMSAN (Acute motor & sensory axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a         

 

Other variants

 

  • Acute motor conduction block neuropathy: GM1a, GD1a
  • Pharyngo-cervico-branchial variant: GT1a
  • Miller-Fischer variant: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Acute ataxic neuropathy: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Pure sensory ataxic variant: GD1b
  • Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis (BBE): GQ1 >> GT1a

 

Reference - Adam and Viktor/Peripheral neuropathy/GBS page 1322

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 24-year-old female who had a lumbar puncture continues to have a headache. Which of the following is not recommended? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluid restriction

 

The patient is experiencing a post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), which can occur after a lumbar puncture due to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). This type of headache is typically treated with a variety of supportive measures to alleviate symptoms and promote healing.

 

Fluid restriction is not recommended for patients with PDPH.  In fact, liberal fluid intake is advised to help replace the lost CSF and maintain adequate hydration, which can aid in reducing the headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low volume blood patch: An epidural blood patch is an effective treatment for PDPH, particularly in refractory cases. It involves injecting a small amount of the patient's own blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Increase caffeine: Caffeine is known to help reduce the severity of PDPH due to its vasoconstrictive properties, which can help alleviate the headache.

 

Option D. Stool softeners: Stool softeners are recommended to prevent straining during bowel movements, which can exacerbate the headache. Constipation is common in postoperative patients due to the use of anesthetics and other medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of post-dural puncture headache, fluid restriction is not recommended. Instead, measures such as epidural blood patches, increased caffeine intake, and stool softeners are utilized to manage symptoms and promote recovery.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is associated with which of the following procedures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Stoppa operation

 

Explanation:

            

The Stoppa operation is the open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair technique for complex inguinal hernias. This procedure involves placing a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space that covers the entire myopectineal orifice bilaterally. It's specifically designed for complex, recurrent, or bilateral inguinal hernias. The Stoppa approach provides excellent coverage of all potential hernia sites while avoiding direct contact with nerves in the inguinal canal, reducing the risk of chronic pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtenstein operation - Incorrect because the Lichtenstein repair is an onlay mesh technique where the prosthetic mesh is placed on top of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, not in the pre-peritoneal space. While it uses mesh, it employs a different anatomical approach and placement technique.

 

Option B. Shouldice operation - Incorrect because the Shouldice repair is a tissue-based herniorrhaphy technique that doesn't use mesh at all. It involves multiple layers of suturing of the native tissue (double breasting of conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament and halves of fascia transversalis) to create a 4-layer posterior wall repair.

 

Option D. Mac-Vay Operation - Incorrect because the McVay (Cooper ligament) repair is another tissue-based repair that doesn't utilize mesh. This technique involves suturing the conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) rather than to the inguinal ligament.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Stoppa operation is characterized by placement of a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space for complex inguinal hernias, covering bilateral myopectineal orifices simultaneously.

questions.text: The chronic alcoholic patient had a history of strenuous exercise but forgot to take his meal, later had alcohol in a party, and presented with hypoglycemia. Which of the following processes is inhibited by alcohol? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gluconeogenesis

 

Alcohol metabolism involves the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetic acid. Both steps generate NADH through the actions of alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, respectively. The excessive production of NADH in the liver causes a shift in the metabolic equilibrium.

 

Increased levels of NADH favor the conversion of pyruvate to lactate (lactic acidosis) and oxaloacetate to malate. Since pyruvate and oxaloacetate are key substrates for gluconeogenesis (the process of generating glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), their depletion inhibits gluconeogenesis. This metabolic inhibition leads to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted, as in the case of the patient who had undergone strenuous exercise and had not eaten.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogenolysis: This process, which involves the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, is not directly inhibited by alcohol. However, once glycogen stores are depleted, the body relies on gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels, which is impaired by alcohol.

 

Option B. HMP shunt: The Hexose Monophosphate shunt (also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway) is involved in generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate but is not directly affected by alcohol metabolism.

 

Option D. Ketone bodies synthesis: While chronic alcohol consumption can lead to ketoacidosis, the synthesis of ketone bodies is not inhibited by alcohol. Instead, alcohol can lead to a buildup of acetyl-CoA, which can actually promote ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH, which inhibits gluconeogenesis by depleting pyruvate and oxaloacetate, leading to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Tolterodine

 

Tolterodine is an anticholinergic drug that is specifically used for treating symptoms of overactive bladder, such as frequent urination, urgency, and incontinence. It works by inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors in the bladder, which reduces bladder contractions and helps manage overactive bladder symptoms.

 

In patients with dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease, the use of anticholinergic medications like tolterodine can be concerning because they can potentially exacerbate cognitive decline due to their effects on the central nervous system. However, tolterodine remains a common treatment option when managing overactive bladder in such patients, especially when other options are limited.

 

Remember –

 

Most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia:

 

Mirabegron >> Trospium (as it has minimal CNS entry) >> Tolterodine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tiotropium: Tiotropium is an anticholinergic drug used as a long-acting inhalational bronchodilator in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It is not used for treating overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Telenzepine: Telenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the treatment of peptic ulcers by reducing gastric acid secretion. It is not indicated for the treatment of overactive bladder.

 

Option D. Tropicamide: Tropicamide is an anticholinergic drug used as an eye drop to induce mydriasis (pupil dilation) and cycloplegia for eye examinations. It is not used for overactive bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolterodine is an appropriate treatment for overactive bladder, but caution is needed in dementia patients due to its anticholinergic properties, which can potentially worsen cognitive function. When selecting an anticholinergic drug for these patients, those with minimal CNS penetration, like trospium, would be preferable if available.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for producing different types of hormones. The mnemonic "GFR" can help remember the order and function of these zones:

 

  • Zona glomerulosa: Produces mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), which are involved in regulating salt and water balance.
  • Zona fasciculata: Produces glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), which play a key role in glucose metabolism, stress response, and immune function.
  • Zona reticularis: Produces androgens (e.g., dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione), which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

The zona fasciculata specifically secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which is involved in various physiological processes including metabolism, immune response, and stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineralocorticoid: This hormone is produced by the zona glomerulosa, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option C. Androgen: These hormones are produced by the zona reticularis, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is produced by the adrenal medulla, not the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

choices.text: Identify the source of bleeding
Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding in the external auditory canal following trauma. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

 

Given the situation of trauma and the presence of blood in the external auditory canal, the most appropriate next step is to keep the ear dry to avoid any additional complications and to provide oral medications for pain, possible infection, and to reduce inflammation.

 

Keeping the ear dry and giving oral medications is a standard approach for managing a bloody discharge from the ear following trauma. This usually includes avoiding water in the ear to prevent infection and prescribing oral antibiotics if there is a suspicion of bacterial infection. Pain relief medication may also be provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirating the clot is generally not the first step in management unless there's a need for immediate assessment of the underlying structures, and if there's concern for ongoing bleeding that may be occluding the canal and impeding examination.

 

Option B. Identifying the source of bleeding is important, especially if the bleeding is significant or ongoing. However, this would typically follow initial conservative management unless the bleeding is profuse.

 

Option D. Syringing (ear irrigation) is contraindicated in the presence of a bloody discharge following trauma, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and increase the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After trauma to the external auditory canal with bloody discharge, it is important to keep the ear dry and initiate treatment with oral medications, such as analgesics and possibly antibiotics, to manage pain, prevent infection, and reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A patient presented with redness and extreme pain in the eye. There is also diminution of vision and discharge after the use of contact lenses. Which organism can be the causative agent here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a protozoan that commonly infects the cornea, particularly in individuals who misuse contact lenses. It is characterized by severe pain that is disproportionate to the clinical signs observed. This is due to the organism’s tendency to infiltrate perineurally, causing intense pain by involving the corneal nerves.

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis often presents with a ring-shaped corneal ulcer, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

 

The culture medium is non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli.

 

The condition is serious and can lead to severe visual impairment if not treated promptly with appropriate anti-amoebic medications such as Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or Propamidine isethionate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria primarily causes systemic infections and is not typically associated with eye infections or contact lens misuse. It is a less common cause of keratitis and does not present with the severe pain characteristic of Acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of bacterial keratitis, often presenting with redness, discharge, and visual impairment. However, it does not cause the extreme pain seen in Acanthamoeba infections, as it does not infiltrate nerves.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterial pathogen that can cause various infections but is not commonly associated with severe pain and the distinct ring-shaped ulcer seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that exceeds clinical findings and is often associated with contact lens misuse, presenting with a distinctive ring-shaped corneal ulcer.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral pons

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons

 

 

Lateral Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The facial nerve or its nucleus leading to ipsilateral facial weakness. (differentiating feature from lateral medullary syndrome).
  • The spinothalamic tract leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Medulla: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract leading to contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The medial lemniscus leading to contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • The hypoglossal nerve leading to ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • This doesn't match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Medial Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract causing contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The abducens nerve leading to ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle palsy.
  • The medial lemniscus causing contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • This doesn't align with the symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lateral Medulla: Lesions in this region (often due to Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome) would result in:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to the involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
  • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus due to vestibular nuclei involvement.
  • Ataxia and dysmetria because of the involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • While some symptoms match, the facial weakness characteristic of facial nerve involvement is not a feature of lateral medullary lesions.
  • If there was no mention of facial weakness then lateral medullary syndrome would had been the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

 

Stroke symptoms

 

Rule of 4’s

 

  1. 4 cranial nerves originate above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 midline cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M 
    • Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    • Medial cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12)
  4. 4 structures to the Side that begin with S 
    • Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
    • Spinothalamic pathway
    • Sensory portion of CN V
    • Sympathetic pathway

questions.text: Identify the prolapse?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele

 

The image shows a Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele, based on the old classification system  classification). In this grading system:

 

  • Grade 1: Prolapse remains inside the vagina.
  • Grade 2: Prolapse reaches the introitus but does not protrude outside.
  • Grade 3: Prolapse extends outside the introitus but not entirely out, and can include anterior vaginal wall prolapse as seen with cystocele.
  • Grade 4 (Procedentia): The entire uterus is outside the introitus.

 

The observed prolapse primarily shows the anterior vaginal wall protruding, indicating a cystocele. A distinguishing feature between Grade 3 and Grade 4 prolapse is the thumb-finger test: if the thumb and finger can approximate over the swelling completely, it indicates Grade 4 prolapse; otherwise, it is Grade 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 3 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect because the protrusion is primarily from the anterior wall, characteristic of a cystocele, not a rectocele (posterior wall).

 

Option C. Grade 2 prolapse with cystocele: This is incorrect as Grade 2 would not extend outside the introitus, whereas the prolapse seen here is visibly beyond the introitus.

 

Option D. Grade 2 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect for the same reasons as Grade 2 cystocele; additionally, the prolapse involves the anterior wall rather than the posterior, ruling out rectocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 3 prolapse extends outside the introitus and can involve cystocele. Differentiating between Grade 3 and Grade 4 requires the thumb-finger approximation test.

questions.text: All are used in recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomerases

 

Isomerases are not used in recombinant DNA technology. Isomerases are enzymes that catalyze structural rearrangements within a molecule, converting one isomer to another. They don't have applications in genetic engineering techniques where cutting, joining, or modifying DNA sequences is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatases: These are used in recombinant DNA technology. Alkaline phosphatase removes terminal phosphate groups from DNA, which is useful in preventing unwanted ligation reactions in DNA cloning.

 

Option B. CRISPR Cas9:
 

CRISPR/CAS 9 System:

  • Causes double strand break
  • CROSPR- Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Cas-9: CRISPR associated endonuclease
    • This endonuclease is guided by CRISPR for cutting site
  • It is an immune system in bacteria against bacteriophages
    • Memory of bacteriophage infection and immunity is transferred to future generation also. So protect may future generations from viruses

Uses

  • Can be adopted to be used in eukaryotes for purposes like
    • Gene deletion
    • Exogenous gene insertion
    • Multigene editing possible
    • Altering gene transcription and regulation 

 

Option D. Terminal transferase: This enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to add nucleotides to the 3' OH end of DNA, which is useful in various molecular biology applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases, which catalyze structural rearrangements within molecules, are not used in recombinant DNA technology or genetic engineering, while phosphatases, CRISPR Cas9, and terminal transferase are utilized in these techniques.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enlarged blind spots

 

The correct answer is Enlarged blind spots. The image shows a significant enlargement of the physiological blind spot, which is a hallmark of conditions such as papilledema. Papilledema is a condition characterized by optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling leads to an enlarged blind spot-on visual field testing, which is prominently seen in the images provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Altitudinal field defects: These defects present as a loss of vision above or below the horizontal line, resembling a band-like defect across the visual field. This type of defect is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy or branch retinal artery or vein occlusion.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate field defects: Arcuate defects appear as arc-shaped visual losses that extend from the blind spot and follow the nerve fiber layer pattern. This type of defect is typically seen in glaucoma and other optic neuropathies.

 

 

Option D. Roennes nasal step: This defect is characterized by a step-like pattern near the nasal visual field, commonly seen in glaucoma. It occurs due to the asymmetry between the superior and inferior nerve fiber bundles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlarged blind spots on visual field testing are indicative of conditions like papilledema, where optic disc swelling leads to an increased physiological blind spot

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

 

The European Hernia Society (EHS) classification for groin hernias includes a designation based on the location and whether the hernia is primary or recurrent. 

 

Refers to a primary hernia occurring laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, which protrudes through the deep inguinal ring. According to the EHS classification, a primary indirect hernia located in the lateral region with defect size 2 finger breadths (3 cm) is labelled as PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary direct: Refers to a primary hernia occurring medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, typically in Hesselbach's triangle. It is labelled as “PM”. 2 refers to size of defect as 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

 

Option C. Recurrent direct: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous direct hernia repair.

 

Option D. Recurrent indirect: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous indirect hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

According to the EHS classification, a hernia labeled as PL2 refers to a primary indirect inguinal hernia that is having a defect of size 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:
