The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of_____ by aspirin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboxane Synthesis

 

Thromboxane A2 is a substance that promotes platelet aggregation and also causes vasoconstriction. Aspirin inhibits the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is crucial for the synthesis of thromboxane A2. By inhibiting thromboxane synthesis, aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, which can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, manifesting as occult blood in the stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phospholipase A2: This enzyme is involved in the initial step of arachidonic acid release from cell membranes, but it is not directly inhibited by aspirin. The effect of aspirin is more downstream in the arachidonic acid pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Phospholipase C is involved in intracellular signaling but is not inhibited by aspirin. It does not play a direct role in the mechanism by which aspirin may cause occult blood in the stool.

 

Option D. Phospholipase D: Similar to Phospholipase C, Phospholipase D is not inhibited by aspirin and is not involved in the mechanism leading to gastrointestinal bleeding from aspirin use.

 

Therefore, in this patient, the occult blood in the stool is most likely due to the inhibition of thromboxane synthesis by aspirin, making option B the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin inhibits thromboxane synthesis by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to reduced platelet aggregation and an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: If division occurs on the 7th day during twin gestation, the result would be: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diamnionic, monochorionic

 

When division of the embryonic mass occurs on the 7th day post-fertilization, the result is diamnionic, monochorionic twins. At this stage, the blastocyst has already formed the outer trophoblast layer (which develops into chorion) but the inner cell mass has not yet differentiated into the bilaminar disk and formed the amniotic cavity. Therefore, division at this point results in two separate embryos with their own amniotic cavities (diamnionic) but sharing a single chorion (monochorionic).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diamnionic, dichorionic: This type results from division occurring earlier, between days 0-3 after fertilization, when the zygote or early blastomeres split. At this early stage, each embryo develops its own chorion and amnion.

 

Option C. Monoamnionic, monochorionic: This results from division occurring later, between days 8-12, after the amniotic cavity has formed but before the embryonic disk differentiates. The embryos share both the amniotic cavity and chorion.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: These result from incomplete division of the embryonic disk, typically occurring after day 13 post-fertilization, when the embryonic axis has begun to form. The division is incomplete, resulting in twins that are physically connected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The timing of embryonic division critically determines the amnionicity and chorionicity of twin pregnancies, with day 7 division specifically resulting in diamnionic, monochorionic twins due to the developmental stage of the trophoblast and inner cell mass at that point.

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax​ without affecting KmKm​.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm​ (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax​ (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax​ and KmKm​ proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
